smell_analysis.justification: No empty diagrams were found. All 19 diagrams contain at least one element. Page 1 has package diagram with multiple packages and actors, pages 2-3 have use cases, page 4 has activity actions, pages 5-13 have classes, page 9 has states, and pages 14-19 have database tables.

On page 2 (Autode funktsionaalne allsüsteem - Vaata & Tuvasta), use cases 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Vaata aktiivseid autosid', 'Vaata kõiki autosid', 'Vaata autode koondaruannet' are all within the Süsteem boundary with actors Uudistaja, Klienditeenindaja, Juhataja, Klient, and Autode haldur positioned around them. On page 3, use cases have associations with Autode haldur and Juhataja. All use case ovals have at least one actor association.

Reviewed all use cases across pages 2 and 3. Page 2 has: Tuvasta kasutaja, Vaata aktiivseid autosid, Vaata kõiki autosid, Vaata autode koondaruannet. Page 3 has: Auto registreerimine, Lõpeta auto, Muuda autot, Aktiveeri auto, Muuda auto mittaktiivseks, Vaata kõiki ootel või mitteaktiivseid autosid, Unusta auto. No duplicate use case names describing the same activity with the same actor were found.

On page 1 (package diagram), each package contains uniquely named elements. 'Autode funktsionaalne allsüsteem' has unique use case names, 'Isikute register' has Isik and Kasutajakonto, 'Klassifikaatorite register' has unique classifier names, 'Töötajate register' has Töötaja and Töötaja_rolli_omamine, 'Autode register' has Auto and Auto_kategooria_omamine, 'Klientide register' has Klient. No duplicate element names within the same package.

Reviewed database tables on pages 14-19. Common columns like 'nimetus' and 'on_aktiivne' appear in multiple tables but represent different contextual data for each classifier/entity type (e.g., Auto_kategooria nimetus vs Riik nimetus). Per the rule, identically named columns in unrelated tables representing different contexts are NOT redundancy. All shared data relationships use proper FK constraints (e.g., isik_id relationships are connected via FK_Klient_Isik, FK_Tootaja_Isik).

Inconsistent naming form detected. On page 2, all use cases start with verbs: 'Tuvasta kasutaja', 'Vaata aktiivseid autosid', 'Vaata kõiki autosid', 'Vaata autode koondaruannet'. On page 3, most use cases start with verbs ('Lõpeta auto', 'Muuda autot', 'Aktiveeri auto', etc.) but 'Auto registreerimine' starts with a noun ('Auto'). This creates mixed naming patterns (some verb-first, one noun-first).

On page 9 (Auto seisundidiagramm), states are: Algus (initial), Ootel, Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne, Lõpetatud, Unustatud. Transitions: Algus→Ootel (initial), Ootel→Aktiivne, Ootel→Unustatud, Aktiivne→Mitteaktiivne, Aktiivne→Lõpetatud, Mitteaktiivne→Aktiivne, Mitteaktiivne→Lõpetatud. All states have at least one incoming transition path.

On page 4 (Auto lõpetamise tegevusdiagramm), actions include: 'Vaata kõiki autosid, mida saab lõpetada', 'Otsi autot', 'Vali auto', 'Lõpeta valitud auto', with decision nodes 'Kas soovib otsida?', 'Kas nimekirjas on eksemplare?', 'Kas näeb eksemplari, mida lõpetada?', 'Kas soovib jätkata?'. The flow shows all actions are reachable from 'Algus' through the decision branches.

Reviewed all class and database diagrams. Page 5 shows multiplicities (1, 0..*, 0..1). Page 6 shows (1, 0..1, 0..*). Pages 7-8 show (0..*, 1). Pages 10-13 show appropriate multiplicities. Database diagrams on pages 14-19 all display multiplicities on both ends (e.g., '0..1', '1', '0..*'). Every relationship has multiplicity indicators on both ends.

Counted central elements per diagram: Page 2: 4 use cases; Page 3: 7 use cases; Page 4: ~6 actions; Page 5: 3 classes (Isik, Töötaja, Auto); Page 6: 6 classes; Page 7: 6 classes; Page 8: 6 classes; Page 9: 6 states; Page 10: 5 classes; Page 11: 3 classes; Page 12: 7 classes; Page 13: 3 classes; Page 14: 4 tables; Page 15: 9 tables (Tootaja_roll, Isiku_seisundi_liik, Auto_kategooria_tyyp, Riik, Tootaja_seisundi_liik, Auto_kytuse_liik, Kliendi_seisundi_liik, Auto_mark, Auto_kategooria); Page 16: 3 tables; Page 17: 6 tables; Page 18: 2 tables; Page 19: 5 tables. Maximum is 9 on page 15. Threshold is ≥10. Since 9 < 10, smell is NOT present.

Counted visual connection lines per element on each diagram. Page 14: Isik has 3 lines (to Kasutajakonto, Isiku_seisundi_liik, Riik). Page 15: Auto_kategooria has 1 line. Page 16: Klient has 2 lines. Page 17: Auto has 5 lines (to Auto_kytuse_liik, Auto_mark, Auto_seisundi_liik, Auto_kategooria_omamine, and the FK relationships shown). Page 18: Auto has 2 lines. Page 19: Tootaja has 4 lines. Maximum is 5 lines (Auto on page 17). Threshold is ≥6. Since 5 < 6, smell is NOT present.

Visual inspection of all diagram layouts shows elements are reasonably spaced. Related elements are positioned near each other (e.g., on page 17 Auto and its related classifiers are grouped together, on page 19 Tootaja and related elements are clustered). No relationship distance appears to exceed twice the average element distance on any diagram.

On page 3, the use case 'Auto registreerimine' does not start with an active verb. 'Auto' is a noun and 'registreerimine' is a nominalized verb (registration). This follows noun-first pattern instead of verb-first pattern like other use cases ('Lõpeta auto', 'Muuda autot', 'Aktiveeri auto', etc. all start with imperative verbs). Activity diagram actions on page 4 all start with active verbs ('Vaata', 'Otsi', 'Vali', 'Lõpeta').

Reviewed all names: Class names - Isik (4 chars), Auto (4 chars), Klient (6 chars), Töötaja (7 chars), Riik (4 chars), etc. All class names have ≥4 characters. Attribute names - e_meil (6), eesnimi (7), nimetus (7), kood (4), parool (6), etc. All attributes have ≥4 characters. Use case names are all descriptive phrases with many characters. Threshold is ≤3 characters. No names found with ≤3 characters.

All class names start with uppercase and are singular: Isik (Person), Kasutajakonto (User account), Töötaja (Employee), Klient (Client), Auto (Car), Klassifikaator (Classifier), Auto_kategooria (Car category), Auto_seisundi_liik (Car status type), etc. No class names start with lowercase or are plural.

Reviewed all attribute/column names across class diagrams (pages 5-13) and database diagrams (pages 14-19). All attributes start with lowercase: e_meil, eesnimi, elukoht, isikukood, perenimi, reg_aeg, nimetus, on_aktiivne, kood, parool, auto_kood, mudel, vin_kood, etc. No attributes or columns start with uppercase letters.

All database table names on pages 14-19 are singular: Isik (not Isikud), Kasutajakonto, Tootaja_roll, Auto_kategooria, Auto_kategooria_tyyp, Auto_kytuse_liik, Isiku_seisundi_liik, Kliendi_seisundi_liik, Riik, Tootaja_seisundi_liik, Auto_mark, Klient, Auto, Auto_kategooria_omamine, Tootaja, Tootaja_rolli_omamine. No plural table names found.

Reviewed all table, class, and attribute names for type prefixes. No type prefixes like tbl_, uc_, str, int found. Table names: Isik, Auto, Klient, etc. (no tbl_ prefix). Attribute names: e_meil, nimetus, isikukood, etc. (no str_ or similar prefixes). The prefixes PK_, FK_, pfK_, and IXFK_ are present but these are explicitly allowed per the rule for indicating primary keys, foreign keys, and indexes.
